title: Werner Fuchs
text:
Werner Fuchs (25 October 1948 – 11 May 1999) was a German <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and coach.
Playing career.
Fuchs was born in <a href="Kaiserslautern">Kaiserslautern</a>. A centre forward, he began his professional career in 1967 with a professional contract at <a href="1.%20FC%20Kaiserslautern">1. FC Kaiserslautern</a>, where is older brother <a href="Fritz%20Fuchs">Fritz</a> also played professionally. Werner Fuchs only appeared once in the first team against <a href="Eintracht%20Braunschweig">Eintracht Braunschweig</a> on 10 February 1968, and would remain his only appearance in the <a href="Bundesliga">Bundesliga</a>. Although he did feature in another Bundesliga team, <a href="Hannover%2096">Hannover 96</a> in 1972, he transferred to the regional league team <a href="SC%20Preu%C3%9Fen%20M%C3%BCnster">SC Preußen Münster</a> in that same season without making an appearance. He played on in Münster until his retirement in 1980.
Coaching career.
His greatest achievements came as a football manager. As trainer of <a href="Alemannia%20Aachen">Alemannia Aachen</a>, he enjoyed huge popularity among the citizens of <a href="Aachen">Aachen</a>. He was trainer there from 1984 to 1987, and then again from 1996 until his death in 1999. He took Alemannia Aachen back into the <a href="2.%20Bundesliga">2. Bundesliga</a>, but was unable to continue his success as a few days before the final league game, which Aachen won to secure promotion, he collapsed during a walk in the woods with the team and died of a heart attack aged 50. He continues to be honoured by Aachen fans today, with signs in the stadium, for example.
Tributes.
On the tenth anniversary of Werner Fuchs' death, Alemannia Aachen announced that the new amateur stadium belonging to the also <a href="New%20Tivoli">New Tivoli</a> stadium would be named the "Werner-Fuchs-Stadion", following suggestions from fans.
